However, the States will get an extra Â£6,800,000 this year for roads and I hope that local governing authorities, particularly in the Labour-controlled States, will demand of their members of parliament that the whole of the money be not only allocated but also distributed to local authorities so that they can get on with the joh.

I wholeheartedly support every section of the budget. I could speak for a long time in praise of it. This Government has made liberal allocations to the States. Indeed, States with Labour governments have received much greater assistance from the Menzies Government than from any previous government. A prominent member of the Labour party said to me, "You people are destroying the Labour party". I asked him to explain his meaning, and he proceeded, "You are handing out all this money to State governments. We believe in unification and the abolition of State parliaments, but so long as you give the States so much money they will be the big fishes in the little pools, and will not listen to us when we advocate unification ".

talk.start.para: .- I have listened with amazement to the speeches of apologists for the Government. The honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hamilton), in my opinion, has handled the truth rather recklessly. The slow rate of construction of houses, hospitals and schools in the States is the real indication of the meagre financial assistance that is provided by the Menzies Government. At this time, it is appropriate for me to remind honorable members of the famous words of a Treasurer some years ago in reply to requests by State premiers foi increased financial assistance from the Commonwealth pool. The Premiers submitted their plans, strongly supported their case and even invited the representative of the Commonwealth to put aside the proposals that he did not like. The Treasurer replied, " Â£200,000,000- not a penny more unless over my dead body". It ill becomes Government supporters to attempt to thrust responsibility onto the States for the lag in the programme for the construction of houses, hospitals and schools. Of course, Government supporters hold State Labour governments in such contempt, and adopt such a hostile attitude towards them as to become a general laughing stock.

speech.para: Honorable members opposite rant about the magnificent victory that they had in the recent general election. They need only one more pyrrhic victory of that kind and many of them will not be here.' The number of votes cast for the Labour party at the last election exceeded by 140,000 the combined votes cast for the Liberal party and the Australian country party. In those circumstances, the Labour party had a moral victory, and no words of the apologist, the Minister for Social Services (Mr. McMahon), can disguise that fact. He has challenged members of the Labour party to take part in this debate. It is well for him to speak about the satisfactory condition of the pensioners. He has been called the millionaire bachelor and the playboy in charge of social services. He tells the people that he is pleased with the treatment that pensioners are to receive under this budget. But hostility to the budget is not confined to the recipients of social services. Approximately 47 per cent, of the people voted for the Government at the last general election, and every one of them has registered, in some degree, his or her disapproval of the present financial proposals. Statements in the press express disappointment with the budget, and describe it variously as contemptible and complicated. The secretary of the United Original Pensioners Association has confirmed our view that the pensioners supported the Government at the last election because they expected a fair deal from it. The secretary is reported to have made the following statement: -

quote.para: We voted for Mr. Menzies because we trusted him. Now we feel he has let us down.

speech.para: Government supporters speak glibly about the stabilization of prices. Yet advice has been received in the last week that the price of tea, which is the principal beverage of pensioners, is to be increased by ls. per lb. This Â£1,000,000,000 budget is a great disappointment to all sections of the community. I thought that the Government, which had a nest egg of about Â£64,000,000 at the end of the last financial year, would have granted substantial benefits to people who had been fleeced for years. This budget has been referred to as being as bad as the horror budget of 1951, which was introduced after the double dissolution. The similarity between the two sets of circumstances is too close to be accidental. No election is pending this year, and, therefore, the Government considers that it does- not need to make any worthwhile concessions to the poor. The Government is not interested in, or worried about, the plight of the people who are in want.

One preliminary to the presentation of budgets in recent years has been the whipping up of war hysteria. The people are beginning to liken this Government to the boy who cried " wolf ". The Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), more than threeand a half years ago, spoke of *he inevitability of war within three years. The Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison), on his return from overseas, spoke of the inevitability of war within two years. The Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden), when the validity of the Defence Preparations Act 1951 was challenged, told the court of the danger of war within twelve months. This technique is not employed by this Government alone. When we were in New Zealand in L950, we listened to an address by Mr.. John Duffenbecker, Q.C., the leader of the Canadian delegation. He was a man of great knowledge and ability, who had represented his country at the United Nations. He told us that no sirens would blow in the United States of America until war was imminent and indeed, the sound of the sirens might herald the dropping of bombs. This war hysteria is whipped up in many places for various reasons.

The nation is mystified at the moment about the Government's defence policy. The Prime Minister, in his statement on the 14th July last, said that Australia was not committed to take part in any war in South-East Asia. He made that announcement in reply to a statement by the central executive of the Australian Labour party to the effect that we were being committed to- conscription. What are the- Government's plans? I claim that confidence has- been destroyed. The Chief of the General Staff has stated that the Army is encountering difficulty in securing recruits. The Government should take the people into its confidence. Et is saying that it cannot do this and that because of the commitments Australia has entered into, overseas; but I believe the people will not continue to accept the plea that, because of the danger of war, we cannot assist people in this country who are in need'. If the Prime Minister- believed for- one moment that war was imminent and that this, country was in danger; I have no doubt that some people now holding important positionsin the Cabinet would not be permitted to continue to, occupy them. If the Prime Minister believed that war was imminent, why did he give- to one of his most incompetent colleagues the important portfolios of Minister for the Army and Minister for the Navy? Many presscomments were made about that decision1. In the Sydney Daily Telegraph of the 9th July, the following, comments were made : -

quote.para: Mr. Menzies, however, has treated Army and Navy very cavalierly. Mr. Francis has not been a very distinguished Minister for the Army and his form is not likely to be improved by having the Navy added to his responsibilities.

speech.para: On the 9th July, the Sydney Daily Mirror stated -

quote.para: It is disappointing to find Mr. Francis still retained as Minister for the Army, a-nd now he has the Navy put on- his plate. Mr. Francis has talked a lot of platitudes. He. does not instil confidence, and the defence of Australia is of paramount importance.

speech.para: As has been said by a number of people, not only in this. Parliament but also outside, it is obvious that the Prime Minister is not worried very much about the prospect of another Avar. If he were, surely to goodness a man of the calibre of the present Minister for the Army would not be given the Navy portfolio as well. He is not even in the Cabinet first eleven. I believe that he is in the second eleven. As I said earlier, the Prime Minister told the Australian Labour party that Australia was not committed to war. We should be told exactly what we are committed to, so that we shall be able to judge the value of the excuses that are being made by the Government for not giving assistance to people in this country who are in need of assistance.

I agree that the free nations must be closely united. I am firmly convinced that the peoples of the world do not want war. They know the horrors that the atomic bomb, the hydrogen bomb and other weapons could inflict on them in a war. Australia must have a forthright leader, a man who can be trusted. We must demonstrate to the world that peace is necessary. With our population of only 9,000,000 people and our magnificent fertile lands, we could be a great asset to the peoples of the free world. We could help to feed the undernourished peoples of Asia. We could be, not an arsenal but a. granary. As a great food-producing country, we could help the people of the free world and prove to countries that at present are under Communist domination that we have a way of life into which they can fit. Mr. Justice Douglas, of the United States Supreme Court, in his talk to us to-day, demonstrated that we can play a great role in the defeat of communism. We can do much for the benefit of mankind and the achievement of peace. But, unfortunately, this Government represents a class of people whose whole life has been devoted to profitmaking. It is concerned mainly with the profits that the people it represents can make from the labour of others, be it in peace or in war. Those people are interested only in the profits they can make from the labour of other people, irrespective of the colour of their skin. They are responsible for most of the difficulties with which we are faced. By their exploitation of native races, they have helped communism to spread throughout the world.

Australia has taken part in two world wars in order to bring justice to the peoples of other lands. Now we ask that justice be done to our own people. The statement of national income and expenditure circulated by the Treasurer shows that 85 per cent, of the people of Australia received only 57 per cent, of the national income last year. To put it in another way, 87 per cent, of the people received only 57 per cent, of the national cake. We on this side of the chamber say that the Australian people 'are entitled to a more equitable deal than they are getting at present. We ask for justice to be done to the servicemen, the blind people, the temporary and permanently incapacitated ex-servicemen and the hundreds of thousands of people who are receiving age, invalid and widows' pensions. I do not expect those people will get much sympathy from the present Minister for Social Services, to whom I have referred as the " single, millionaire playboy of the Government ". He has been put in charge of the Department of Social Services because he has very little interest in the people generally. For a time he occupied the glamorous positions of Minister for Air and Minister for the Navy, but now he has been selected by the Government to hold the social services portfolio. He has displaced a man who did a reasonably good job in that office, and showed some interest in representations made to him from this side of the Parliament. But apparently he was too sympathetic to the pensioners, because the Government has replaced him with a man, who, quite obviously, has no interest in them. The position was summed up very well in a letter written to the press recently by a pensioner. It read as follows : -

quote.para: Why pity pensioners! The aged, invalid crippled, sick and dying can now leave their beds with this budget, and gu out and do a day's washing or cleaning to the tune Â»i Â£3 10s. a week. Could any government be more generous, apart from supplying free gas chambers for the use of those past doing anything and unable to cope with the tragic struggle to keep alive? The Fair Rents Court has raised my rent from Â£1 to 32s. (id. a weak, leaving me 37s. Cid. to buy food, clothing, electricity, etc., and to pay for occasional help to keep mc decently clean, as 1 am 80 years of age and nearly crippled with arthritis.

speech.para: Iii my office at Bondi Junction on Saturday mornings and at the Federal Members' Rooms in the Commonwealth Bank Building in Martin-place during the week, I hear many stories of the tragic plight of unfortunate pensioners, 350,000 of whom are trying to live on pensions of Â£3 10s. a week. I plead with the Government to take special care of the aged, the invalid and other needy citizens. Here is an opportunity for it to make a name for itself that will go down in Australian history. After all, most of these people have contributed over many years to the cost of government, and even to the National Welfare Fund, which was brought into existence for the purpose of financing social services and which, when the Labour party left office, had a credit balance of Â£189,000,000. Had that fund been continued, it would have amounted to well over Â£300,000,000 to-day. The money in the fund was subscribed for the purpose of providing adequate payments to needy members of the community. I suggest that, if the Government does not want to accept the responsibility of administering repatriation and social services pensions, it should establish an all party committee of members of the Parliament to deal with the task. The important issues of health, repatriation and social services should not be treated like party political footballs. A joint committee of the Parliament could investigate the needs of pensioners in an atmosphere clear of political bickering, and I am sure that it would be able to make sound recommendations. Such committees have worked successfully in the past, and I believe that excellent results would be achieved if the Government would adopt my suggestion. I also believe that pensions should be tied to the basic wage, subject to certain safeguarding provisions against petty reductions.

A review of medical benefits is urgently needed. The Government should put an end to its pettifogging treatment of people under the medical benefits scheme. It is of no use for it to hedge on this issue. The disgraceful truth is that, immediately after the last election campaign, the pharmaceutical benefits available to pensioners were reduced. Apparently a doctor is not allowed to prescribe more than a certain quantity of various drugs at one consultation, with the result that it is often necessary for a pensioner to travel backwards and forwards a number of times in order to obtain additional prescriptions. I wonder why this regulation has been introduced? Is it because the British Medical Association has a complete stranglehold on the Government? Pensioners should be provided with all the life-saving drugs that they need in time of sickness. The Â£10 funeral allowance that was made available for pensioners about ten years ago has never been increased, and the result is that, when a pensioner dies, we often hear of other unfortunate pensioners struggling to raise enough money to provide the cost of a decent funeral. That is a shocking travesty of justice, which no government with any decency or strength of character would tolerate. Child endowment has not been increased for many years. The unemployment and sickness benefit, the maternity allowance and other social service payments also are inadequate under present conditions. The Government had a golden opportunity, with the surplus millions at its command at the end of 1953-54, to make provision in the present budget for the needs of the many people in Australis who are living in dire circumstances.

Undue delay occurs in the payment of social service benefits in New South Wales, and I believe the situation is much the same in other States. Such delays inflict severe hardships on applicants for age, invalid and widows' pensions. I have heard of delays extending up to three months. This is inexcusable. The Minister for Social Services could rehabilitate himself as a member of the Government by putting an. end to such delays. The 37 clauses in the questionnaire that has to be completed by an applicant for a pension are iniquitous. I object particularly to what is described as the " personal long acquaintance " clause, which requires a person who has know the applicant for a period of twenty years to state the circumstances in which the applicant has been living during the twelve months preceding the application. It is not right that friends or neighbours should be called upon to pry into the affairs of unfortunate citizens who wish to claim a. pension, in order to learn exactly how they have been living. The Minister for Social Services has a big job ahead of him. if he is to discharge his responsibilities faithfully. All of the anomalies that I have mentioned should be remedied at the earliest opportunity, and the honorable gentleman should do his utmost to help these unfortunate persons, whose sufferings to-day are pitiful.

Ambulance authorities should not have to bear the cost of providing ambulance services for aged pensioners. Ambulance organizations in all parts of Australia are obliged to seek public assistance. They rely largely on the efforts of willing citizens who make street collections on their behalf. Every Saturday morning at Bondi Junction, for example, such people operate spinning wheels in order to raise funds for the ambulance services. Notwithstanding their financial difficulties, these organizations invariably help invalid and age pensioners in distress. They should not be obliged to shoulder that responsibility. The Australian Government, through the Department of Social Services or the Department of Health, should contribute to the operating costs of ambulances. I hope the Minister will give earnest attention to my representations on this subject. I have frequently asked Ministers to recognize in some way the need for relief of sons and daughters of pensioners in hospitals. On one occasion I specifically asked the Treasurer what could be done to assist relatives of pensioner patients and of pensioners who die. I consider that, at the least, the cost of funeral expenses, and contributions to the upkeep of pensioners in hospital, should be allowable as deductions for income tax purposes. The Treasurer advised me, in reply to my question, to wait until I knew what the budget for 1954-55 contained.. I waited patiently, but I find now that no help will be given to these unfortunate people under the provisions of the budget.

We on this side of the chamber abhor communism and nazi-ism. We oppose dictatorship either of the left or of the right. The platform upon which the Labour movement was founded is the policy that the Labour movement will fight for in this Parliament until it is implemented. We believe that every citizen in the community should share in the benefits of the country's progress. Many thousands of our best citizens have earned the right to adequate social service and repatriation pensions, to hospital and sickness benefits, to ownership of their own homes, to security in employment, and to a proper pride in this, their own country. Therefore, I appeal to the Government to take into consideration the matters that I have raised. I ask it to consider the plight of people who are in want, because many of whom fought for our defence in two world wars or allowed their sons or daughters to serve the country in its time of need. Surely to heaven they are entitled, as a right, to the benefits that I have mentioned! I ask you, Mr. Temporary Chairman, as one who has some genuine interest in the welfare of the people, to see what influence you can bring to bear upon this Government to persuade it to make proper use of the surplus of Â£54,000,000 that was left in the Treasury from the budget of 1953-54.

Mir. FREETH (Forrest) [10.8].- The average householder, if he has to prepare a budget of his receipts and expenditure, is bound by the very simple precepts laid down by Mr. Micawber. The Government has vastly greater responsibilities, but the Opposition has a task even easier than that of the householder or Mr. Micawber. The Opposition, unlike Mr. Micawber, advocates a lower rate of tax - in other words, a greatly diminished revenue - and, at the same time, with an air of cheerful irresponsibility, it advocates extravagance in every avenue of government expenditure. When the Government considers the sums that it must expend, it is required also to balance that essential expenditure against the amount that the community can afford to provide. Its attitude towards this difficult task has a vital influence on the health of the nation.

I think it is agreed that, we are undergoing a period of great expansion. I put the proposition to the committee that, at a time when the nation is passing through such a period, a lesser portion of the total national earnings should be taken by the Government than at other times. In other words, at such a time a greater portion should be left in the hands of the individuals and the business enterprises of the country, who are planning in their own way to develop and' expand the national production. To-night we have heard a very scratchy record played by the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward).[Quorumformed.] I should thank the honorable member for Watson (Mr. Curtin) for his solicitude in providing me with an audience if his action was not typical of the course usually followed by honorable members opposite when remarks are being made that they do not entirely like. Before the interruption, I remarked that we had heard, once again, a very scratchy gramophone record on the subject of company profits played by the honorable member for East Sydney. If honorable members opposite object to business concerns making large profits - and I ask them to think carefully about this matter - which is the aim and object of every business, then, in principle, they object to any business making a profit.

talk.start.para: - Not at all!

- If they object to the making of profit, they object to the ordinary system of private enterprise on which this country is run, and they advocate some other system. However, I shall not enlarge on that contention. As I have said before, the extent of governmental expenditure must be decided in the light of the minimum requirements of the nation, and have regard to the amount of money that a government can take from the people and still leave the country in a healthy state from the point of view of private individuals advancing their own concerns. During the past twelve months a state of stability and full employment has been attained. Those two things combined, as has been suggested by an honorable member opposite, constitute a precarious state of affairs. With that proposition I agree fully, because, from time to time, a very fine balance has to be maintained by a government. It is a very easy matter for a state of full employment to develop into a state of over-full employment, when we immediately lose stability. On the other hand, if we preserve stability to such an extent that there is a tendency for prices and costs to fall, there is a possibility that we might reach a stage in which there is a considerable degree of unemployment. The late Lord Keynes was one of the first economists to propound the idea that, in a free enterprise economy, financial stability is a precarious balance that has to be maintained by government planning and regulation. Labour has fallen down completely in constructive thinking designed to maintain the precarious balance of stability and full employment. Only by the maintenance of such balance can we, in this country, make full use of all our man-power and resources without causing hardship. When this Government commences to prepare estimates of its revenue and expenditure, it is faced with an additional problem, relating not only to its own necessary expenditure, but also to the proportion of revenue to be allocated to the States. If my first proposition that there is a limit to the amount that can be collected at any time from the people of the country is correct, it follows that there is also a limit to the amounts which can be allocated to the States and retained for its own expenditure.

speech.para: I suggest that the arguments that have been directed by members of the committee to the question of the States not receiving adequate money for their needs are false, having regard to the magnitude of the problem. For instance, both Queensland and New South Wales have managed to achieve a substantial budget surplus. In Western Australia, due to difficulties peculiar to that State, in spite of the fact that all States received more than the formula allocation, there is a budget deficit. I do not know how the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the States will be resolved ultimately, but I do know that the States cannot continue to ask the Commonwealth for grants of money for specific purposes and expect to retain full control in relation to their own budgets and the amounts allocated to them by the Commonwealth. This observation applies particularly to the subject of education. During the last few weeks, some of the State governments and people connected with State education have asked the Commonwealth to participate in, and provide money for educational purposes. If the Commonwealth were to usurp the functions of the States in regard to education then each of the States concerned would have to receive less, by the amount of expenditure involved, in their ordinary allocations from Commonwealth funds. Alternatively, the Commonwealth would have to levy increased taxes, or expend less money on its own functions. Those are the only three answers to the proposition. I have not heard any one who has asked that the Commonwealth grant the States funds for education advocate that the people should be taxed more to provide those funds. I have not heard anybody suggest that the States should receive correspondingly less in the amounts allocated to them by the Commonwealth. I notice that, despite all this alleged shortage of funds in the States, certain States still manage to achieve a budget surplus. I have not heard any one on the Opposition side of the chamber suggest that the Commonwealth should expend less money on its own functions.

The three main items of Commonwealth expenditure on its own functions are defence, development and social services. I do not propose to deal with the first two. I wish to confine my remarks to-night to the problem of social services. A few weeks ago honorable members opposite had, to all outward appearances at any rate, a policy in regard to social services. We have not heard them enunciate that policy during this debate. During the last election campaign the Labour party made a specific promise that, if elected to office, it would abolish the means test. It also proposed to increase the basic rate of pension from Â£3 10s. a week to Â£4 a week. It is true that many members of the Labour party were unhappy about that policy, and that the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. W. M. Bourke) had the courage to express his disagreement with it, for which he was promptly disciplined. During this debate, at a time when the Government has carried out its election promises in regard to social services, and when we might expect the Labour party solidly to defend its own social services policy, what do we get from honorable gentlemen opposite? No policy! Nothing except the usual synthetic sobs and crocodile tears for the pensioners.

Social services are a very real problem. There is, at any given stage in any community, a limit to the burden that can be placed on the taxpayer for the provision of social services. The Government's approach to the problem has been fundamentally more sound than that of the Labour party, for the simple reason that we on this side of the chamber have tried to look at the problem as it really is, without regard to vote-catching. The question of abolishing or extending the means test certainly has popular appeal, but the objective of any government that is using the taxpayer's money to provide social services should surely be to meet the needs of the people who are to receive those services. If it be admitted that social services are based on the relative need of those concerned, then it must be admitted that the means of people to satisfy their own needs must be taken into consideration.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable gentleman believe that the means test should be applied in connexion with the payment of child endowment and maternity allowance ?

- I am dealing at the moment with the means test in relation to pensioners. We might consider that we could go a certain way in relaxation of the means test in order to encourage people to provide for their old age; but we cannot go the whole way while there are limits to the ability of the national income to provide for these things, or while there are people at the bottom of the pension scale who are suffering hardship. The person who receives least in the way of social services deserves consideration. I think that all honorable members will agree with me that the pensioner who receives, at the present, Â£3 10s. a week, and nothing more, because he or she is single and alone, and has no home or family, is the person who is obviously under the greatest hardship, and so should be next on the list to be considered should any increases of pensions be advocated.

- In answer to the honorable gentleman, it has already been demonstrated to-night in this House that this Government has raised the flat rate of pension to a higher percentage relationship to the " C " series, or cost of living index, than the Labour party ever did.
- Rubbish !
- Order!

- What is more, honorable members opposite are complaining about the fact that the budget provides for no increase of pension, only because, during the lifetime of this Government, not only have pensions been increased in every budget it has produced, but the flat rate of pension has been increased, whereas- when the Labour party was in office, year after year no increase of that rate was granted. It is only because of the -Government's excellent record in this regard that the Labour party is now trying to use our past, wholesome attitude towards the problem of the bottom rate of pension for the purpose of making political capital out of it.

speech.para: The next point I wish to make is that present pension issues can be broadly stated as concerning either the question of the means test or the question of the lowest rate of full pension. I suggest, for the consideration of the committee, that that is rather like the old saying about Army issue clothing - that there are only two sizes, too big and too small. The pattern of clothing, so to speak, in our pensions system has to be tailored in different ways to meet individual needs. Every individual of pensionable age has his or her own requirements. The people who have the greatest need are the people who are alone, without family or home of their own. This Government has done a good thing by giving money for the provision of homes for pensioners in those circumstances. I say that the next step should be to provide .a housing allowance for pensioners who have not got their own homes. If we are going to provide different sorts of pensions to meet the needs of different people, I suggest that any increase of the lowest rate of pension, which is the flat rate, should be towards providing a greater amount of money for single pensioners, who have no partner of pensionable age who is eligible to receive an equal amount of Dension. An income from pension of Â£7 a week for a married couple provides them with relatively greater means of livelihood than a pension of Â£3 10s. a week provides for a single person. Thus, there is ample justification for saying that there should be a differential rate for married couples who are both receiving pensions. An examination of the social services system in operation in other countries will show that that principle is applied overseas.

talk.start.para: - Would the honorable gentleman discourage matrimony?

- Most people by that time have made up their minds on that subject. I also suggest that an inducement should be offered to pensioners to provide for their own voluntary superannuation systems. I consider that the Government, following the same sort of policy that it has followed in regard to health and medical benefits, should discuss with insurance companies, which are expert in these matters, the possibility of a subsidized voluntary contributory scheme. There are some traps in every compulsory or voluntary contributory scheme for age pensioners, but if this proposition is considered to be attractive, I suggest that as a start it could be a voluntary scheme carried out in conjunction with insurance companies, which, after all, are in the main mutual companies which do not operate for profit, or whose profits are distributed among the members. The other proposition I wish to advance in regard to age pensioners is that there has been a tendency - and it was part of Labour's policy during the last election campaign - to assert that the actual assets of pensioners should not be taken into consideration in connexion with the means test. In other words, if a man had saved Â£5,000, the means test could be applied only to the income from that asset and not to the capital. At present, the taxpayer is paying for the maintenance of aged pensioners. Yet, honorable members opposite, during the general election campaign, advocated that the pensioner, who is maintained by the rest of the community, should be entitled to preserve his assets intact and hand them on to his heirs. I do not think that that proposition can be logically supported.- I would hesitate to advocate any policy which would discourage people from saving money, and I suggest that the Government should provide, in exchange for any capital sum that the pensioner may have saved, a subsidized annuity. A pensioner could hand his capital to the Government and ask that, in return, he be given an annuity for the rest of his life.
- That would be a penalty on thrift.

speech.para: Mr.FREETH.- It would be if the annuity rates that have been adopted by insurance companies were maintained. But insurance companies do not like this class of business. It is a gamble, and the insurance companies contend that the aged person who wants to buy an annuity from them is a person who, because of his family history or for some other reason, expects to beat the insurance company and make a profit. If the Government were to introduce a scheme which would offer a substantial inducement to insurance companies to sell annuities, other people would be attracted.For example, the annuity rate for Â£100 for a male aged 65 is only Â£9 2s. a year, as actuarially calculated by insurance companies. If the Government were to give some guarantee to the insurance companies with regard to the annuity, either in respect of the annual amount, or by setting a maximum time limit to the liability of the companies, then the insurance companies should be able to quote substantially better rates.

Summed up, my submission with regard to age pensioners is that the property limit as provided in the budget is sound. A married couple, both drawing a pension, and one or both of them earning the maximum permissible amount, can own their own home and have an income of Â£14 a week. It cannot rightly be suggested that that is a hardship. I suggest that the Government has done as much as any government could do at the expense of the community in that particular direction, in providing for the hardship that is incidental to old age. As for people who receive a pension of only Â£3 10s. a week, it is fallacious to argue that it would be a simple matter to increase that amount. This would necessitate increasing all rates of pensions and, as I have said, some pensioners are already receiving an adequate amount. If we are not to saddle ourselves with an overwhelming burden and if we, as an expanding community, are not to sacrifice living standards, then our social security objectives must be closely examined. "We should fix the limits of the welfare state. The Government has done a great deal to benefit pensioners. It introduced free medical benefits. This year, it introduced facilities for financing home building. This is a refreshing approach to the problem and I hope that the Government will continue to expand its social services along these lines.

talk.start.para: .- In view of what was said during the foreign affairs debate that took place in this chamber, one would have thought that the Treasurer (Sir ArthurFadden) would have said more about defence in his budget speech. A gloomy picture of the defence of Australia was painted in the course of the debate on foreign affairs. Yet very little was said about defence in the budget speech. The Minister for Social Services (Mr. McMahon), in answering a point that was raised by a member of the Opposition regarding the Government's failure to spend the Â£260,000,000 that was set aside for defence during the last financial year, made the excuse that this sum was not spent because theexpenditure would not have been justified. That reason may be quite sound, but in view of the defence projects that are awaiting attention in this country it is a wonder that any of the Â£200,000,000 should have been left over from the last financial year.

speech.para: A few days ago, I directed a question to the Minister for Defence (Sir Philip McBride) regarding the establishment of a naval base at Fremantle. I also asked why the Neptune Squadron had been taken away from Pearce and I asked whether it was the intention of the Government to replace that squadron. The Minister's reply may be summed up in the last paragraph of his remarks which read as follows: -

quote.para: The strategic advantages which would result from a naval dockyard with docking facilities being provided in the Western Australian area are fully appreciated. They are not, however, of sufficient priority in the naval programme to be undertaken at present.

speech.para: The Minister also refused to replace the Neptune Squadron at Pearce. One would expect that if the Government were taking the subject of defence seriously it would take action for the defence of the western coastline of Australia and of the Northern Territory.

Some reference should also have been made in the budget speech to the transport problems which have faced this nation for a number of years. Very little was said .about that subject. As the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) said, the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) made Only a token suggestion in regard to the vital subject of the standardization of rail gauges. I invite the attention of honorable members to two extracts from a report entitled Defence and Development 1950-53. That is a most important report, and the parts 'Of it to which I desire to direct the .attention of honorable members refer particularly to the well-being and progress <of the Commonwealth. On page 6 the report states -

quote.para: Transport progress lias been slower. In 1950, the transport system was unable to handle the freight offering. Resources are now available to handle all freight coming forward, but some serious weaknesses remain in shipping, railways, and roads, and transport reserves are inadequate to meet any substantial! increase in industrial production or a defence crisis. The efficiency and cost structure of shipping still leaves much to bc? desired.

speech.para: On page 63 of the same report the following sentence appears: -

quote.para: Big programmes of work remain outstanding, and there is still much to be done before the Australian railway systems could meet n wai- emergency.

speech.para: Those extracts from the report speak for themselves, and it is most regrettable that a statement of policy was not made in the budget speech about those important matters. It is astonishing that the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) did not mention the standardization of railway gauges throughout Australia The vital matter of uniform railway gauges is raised in this Parliament only during the course of a war, or a war emergency. Immediately the defence urgency disappears, standardization of rail gauges is .shelved and forgotten. Then when another emergency arises, the matter comes up again for consideration and more reports are called for. I am most concerned because the report made by Sir Harold Clapp on the standardization of rail gauges, and presented to the Parliament in March, 1945, has been put aside. Of course the shelving of this type of report is not new, and many other similar reports have been laid aside. A report on uniform rail gauges was presented by a royal commission set up to inquire into the matter in 1921. The commission went into the subject very thoroughly, and ultimately reported that :at that time the cost of standardizing rail gauges throughout the mainland to a gauge of -4 ft. 8$ in. would have been Â£57,200,000.

During the past three years, in accordance with the report on defence and development, about Â£466,000.000 has been expended on defence. Two hundred million pounds was allocated to defence for the last financial year, but only .Â£177,000,000 of that money was expended. For the present financial year the Government has set aside Â£212,000,000. It appears to me that quite a large proportion of the money that has been allocated for defence purposes during the past four years or so could have been used to much greater advantage in standardizing rail gauges. There is no doubt that much of the money allocated for defence has been wasted, and perhaps if the amount so wasted had been used for rail standardization we would have had a uniform gauge throughout Australia to-day. It is appreciated in all quarters that a primary defence need is the ability to move troops, equipment and supplies quickly from all parts of Australia to threatened areas. In that connexion I direct the attention, of honorable members to page 11 of the-report of Sir Harold Clapp where the following occurs : -

quote.para: The justification for the standardization of gauges must, of course, vest primarily on defence rather than on economic grounds.

speech.para: Sir Harold Clapp appended to his report a letter from the then Acting Minister for the Army to the then Acting Prime Minister and Minister for Defence. That letter is dated the 22nd April, 1944, and the second paragraph of it reads -

quote.para: The defence aspect of this problem is of vital importance if indeed it does not of itself present a real justification for an undertaking of such magnitude in the -field of Post-war Construction.

speech.para: That was the opinion of the Department of the Army at that time. It is most regrettable that important opinions like those that I have mentioned have been shelved, and it seems that nothing further will be done about rail standardization, although we have been warned of a present war emergency by the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies). Sir Harold Clapp made further statements in his report, which I believe are very important, and I therefore put them before the chamber. He said -

quote.para: While the Commissioners of the respective railway systems believe that only limited economics in operation will be secured from standardisation of gauges, I consider that the direct and indirect economics will ultimately be very great. These economics, however, will be secured not by maintaining a State outlook but by the railway systems being viewed as a whole from a national standpoint. Standardisation of rolling stock and the free interchange which this would permit throughout Australia, will not only reduce both capital and maintenance expenditures but will place the Railways in a position to offer a much higher standard and greater service to the community. Australia's increasing population will, of course, necessitate improved services to cope with heavier demands for transport. It is obvious that unrestricted and faster transport of primary products from the producing areas to the points of manufacture, consumption, or shipment overseas will be of the greatest value to industry. The conveyance of live stock, chilled meat, perishable produce, etc. over long distances without transfer will eliminate the delays and deterioration which are inescapable under present conditions. Gauge conversion will undoubtedly place the railways in a position to meet all these essential needs.

Moreover, standardisation of gauges will in no small measure tend to break down State prejudices and be an ever-growing influence in developing a national, as opposed' to a State outlook on the part of the people of Australia. It was the experience in both Great Britain and the United States of America that diversity of railway gauges retarded national development and the advent of a uniform gauge initiated an era of increasing cooperation and a broader national outlook which rapidly broke down the artificial barriers between communities. It is believed in the United States of America that unified gauge has not only contributed very largely to the unity of the nation in welding the railways into one great transport system but has played its part in making the people of that country unconscious of their State' boundaries.

speech.para: Honorable members will consequently perceive that Sir Harold Clapp drew attention to the great value of a standardized rail system to the Commonwealth, not only in time of war but also in time of peace. At present, because of breaks of gauge, passengers and goods have to be transhipped from train to train at State borders. Honorable members well know the number of breaks of gauge that are met with on the train journey from Perth to Canberra, for example, and the inconvenience caused by changing from one train to another. While the section of the line from Albury to Canberra is not particularly important, it is most important that rail gauges from Fremantle to Brisbane should be standardized as a first step towards the complete standardization of Australian railway systems. Quite apart from the convenience that such standardization would ensure, big financial savings could be effected. That is because locomotives and rolling stock would not have to be changed at State borders, and freight and passengers would be able to travel right through, without a break, from one end of Australia to the other. The longer this important work is deferred, the greater the cost will be. It could have been done comparatively cheaply in 1921. When Sir Harold Clapp submitted his report in 1945 also, it could have been done cheaply, compared with what it would cost to-day. Nevertheless, the cost would be lower to-day than in twenty years' time. That is why the Government should do something about this important matter. The estimated cost of Sir Harold Clapp's A, B and C proposals was Â£76,751,000. That was a relatively small sum, having regard to present-day costs, but the point to remember is that the cost will increase with each year that this national project is uncompleted. I appreciate, of course, that certain difficulties, such as that of reaching agreement with the States, exist in regard to this matter. Disagreements have arisen about the allocation of costs, but such disagreements should not be insurmountable. In my opinion, every effort should be made to reach agreement now. In 1945, the State Premiers resolved that the work of standardization "should be proceeded with as being essentia] to national defence and development". Draft agreements were drawn up at that time, but unfortunately, disagreement occurred and nothing more was done.

A royal commission was set up in Western Australia to inquire into the rail transport system. While that commission was sitting, the State Government reopened with the Australian Government the question of standardization of railway gauges, with a view to seeing whether plans could be agreed upon and incorporated in the general plan for the rehabilitation of the Western Australian railways. There was a joint investigation by a committee which consisted of representatives of the Western Australian Government and the Australian Government. The report of the committee was headed, " A report on standardization and modernization of the Western Australian Government railways " and was dated March, 1949. It was tabled in both Houses of the Parliament, but nothing resulted from it. In that report, the committee discussed the estimated cost of rehabilitation and modernization of the 3-ft. 6-in. gauge in Western Australia, and arrived at a figure of Â£26,000,000. An alternative plan for standardization and modernization, the estimated cost of which was Â£62,000,000, was submitted by the committee. Although the committee did not recommend the immediate standardization of railway gauges in Western Australia, it made this reference ro that subject on page 7 of the report -

quote.para: The technical officers consider that utlimately the growth of traffic will render standardization economic and necessary. This would result in greater total expenditure than if standardization were undertaken within the next 20 years.

speech.para: That is very important. The committee considered that something should be done urgently in order to avoid inflated costs. Their report went beyond the limit set by Sir Harold Clapp, who, in the first place, recommended conversion of the line from Kalgoorlie to Fremantle, and standardization of the remainder of the system after that stage had been completed.

I suggest to the Government that these negotiations should be re-opened with the Western Australian Government, with a view to seeing whether agreement can be reached. The ball could be set rolling by the standardization of the railway gauge between Kalgoorlie and Fremantle, and at the same time, consideration could be given to implementation of Sir Harold Clapp's A, B and C proposals.

If we look at this matter from a defence point of view, it must be obvious that a standardized gauge would break down the isolation of Western Australia.- In addition, it would provide more comfortable travel, remove the barriers against the proper flow of traffic, reduce the cost of transporting goods, passengers and mails, and also reduce operating costs, because locomotives and rolling-stock could be used on the railway systems of other States. Many railway experts believe that a uniform railway gauge would pay for itself over a given period, because of the reduced costs that would result from it.

Bail transport is the cheapest form of land transport there is. It is true that the transport of goods by sea is cheaper than it is by rail, but of course, sea transport is not nearly as convenient as is land transport. With the increasing use of diesel engines, greater economy and improved efficiency are being achieved. Rail traffic is coming into its own. It is very important that our railway systems should be modernized and standard gauges introduced. I wish to refer to a significant statement in the report from which I have just quoted. This section of the report indicates the difficulties with which Western Australia is faced, due to its large area and small population. On page 13 of the report, the following comment appears : -

quote.para: Occupying nearly one-third of the total area of the Commonwealth, Western Australia has only one-fifteenth of the population. Lines of communication are long and density of traffic low, and in the result the transport problem in Western Australia is of unusual importance. Illustrative of this are the indicators set out below, which show that the transport requirements of the State are relatively greater than for Australia as a whole.

speech.para: The report then proceeds to give the following detailed information : -

Honorable members should appreciate the difficulties with which Western Australia is faced in trying to modernize its railways and introduce a standard gauge without Commonwealth assistance. Similar difficulties arise in respect of other forms of transport in Western Australia, but at the moment I am dealing only with rail transport. The population of Australia is increasing. As Western Australia becomes more highly industrialized, its population will grow. If industry in that State is to thrive, the railways will have to be improved. The State Government cannot do that without financial assistance from the Commonwealth. The cost of such modernizationand standardization may not beas great as some honorable members think, because the Western Australian Government railways are purchasing locomotives with a view to their use on broad-gauge lines.For instance, 68 diesel locomotives which have been orderedcould be converted to the broadgauge system merely by fitting different bogies. The cost, therefore, may not be great, having regard to the groundwork that is being done at the present time. The important matter is not the cost of these projects but their relation to defence.

I draw the attention of honorable members to the unbiased statement of a person who was not associated with Australian railways but who was called upon to present a report to the Victorian railway authorities on the subject of transport. The report, which was made by Mr, John Elliot, a member of the Instituteof Transport (England), was banded down on the 20th May, 1949. Mr. Elliot was invited to review the question of transport generally in Victoria. Although it was not part of his task, he discussed the unification of rail gauges in Australia, and made the following statement : -

quote.para: I believe that the present railway systems in Australia, with their varying gauges and consequent transfer points, are unsuitable for a country of great distances populated by one people of the same race and Commonwealth. So Jong as the vexatious restrictions on free railway passage of freight and passengers from one part oftheCommonwealth to another persist, the railways will continue to be worked under adverse technical and operating conditions, to the detriment of the national well-being.

With separate State systems working to varying gauges, standardization of equipment of all kinds is impossible. Without such standardization, the cost of railway working is unnecessarily high and wasteful.

Economies in handling of interstate, and intra-state traffic offer themselves through standardization of gauge and Tolling stock; while through the total elimination of exchange points economy in labour will be secured, and transit of traffic remarkably speeded up.

I believe that standardization of railway gauge in Australia is bound to come, sooner or later. From the point of view of long-term planning of railway development, onwhich so much depends, the sooner the decision is taken, the betterfor Australian transport, and therefore Australian industry. After the decision istaken, at least five years will elapse during which the new 4 ft. 8Â½ in. gauge rolling stock is being built, before any considerable labour force can be employed on track conversion.

With standardization of gauges should come unification of all the Australian railway systems underone Federal control and organization, as in South Africa and on the Canadian National Railways. Only in this way will the Commonwealth obtain the greatest advantages from the traffic and technical aspects which unification alone can bring.

Fromthe defence point of view, I imagine that the transport problems of the last war have shown how great are the shortcomings of a disunited railway system, which had to be supplemented at a very heavy cost by road and airtransport absorbing far more labour inthetransport of a given tonnage than would have been the case if the Australian Railways had been of a standardized and unified structure.

speech.para: That is a very important statement, of which the House should take notice.

It is mot sufficient that such reports should be shelved and that nothing should be done about them from one emergency to another. It is always argued that expense enters into such matters, but I repeat that the question of expense should not be considered when the important subject of defence is before us.I agree with Sir Harold Clapp, Mr. John Elliot, and other people who believe that Australia should have a standardized rail gauge as soon as possible, particularly in view of the imminent threat from South-East Asia. Let us do something, and put this plan for national development into effect as soon as possible.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: . - Yesterday afternoon the Minister for Defence Production (Sir Eric Harrison) was guilty of deliberately misleading the House-
- Order ! The honorable member may not use such terms.

speech.para: He must withdraw the word " deliberately ".

talk.start.para: - I withdraw the word" deliberately", but the Minister was guilty of misleading, the House on the subject of the technical report upon certain complaints to, which I referred in the House last week in relation to the manufacture of Canberra aircraft components by Chrysler Australia Limited. I maintain - and I shall prove it in a few minutes by quoting from a report - that the action of the light honorable gentleman was a serious, breach of ministerial responsibility, because it is the responsibility of the Minister to report truthfully to the House the contents of a report of this kind. The Minister said, amongst other things, that all of the complaints to which I referred were fantastically absurd.
- Hear, hear!
- Do not say " Hear, hear ! "
- The Minister proved that they were absurd.
- The Minister tabled the report of the technical inquiry without reading, it, and he made the following statement -

quote.para: Summarizing the report, there is no foundation in the allegation that has been made that the company is guilty of serious negligence in the manufacture of parts and components for the Canberra aircraft or that any faulty part from Chrysler Australia Limitedhas been fitted which would in any way affect the safety of the aircraft.

speech.para: See how cleverly the right honorable gentleman dodged the issue.For a start, he was leading the House to believe that there was no evidence that any faulty part had been fitted to the aircraft. He deliberately evaded reading the report that was submitted by the committee of technicans, and instead he read a report that obviously was prepared by a different person or persons from those who sat on the technical inquiry. That report was careful to avoid reference to sections of the technical report, which not only supported the claim that Chrysler Australia Limited had produced faulty Canberra components but also went so far as to state that some of those components had actually been assembled into an aircraft before the error was detected.
The Minister, in excusing himself for not revealing those serious admissions in the technical report, made the following statement -

quote.para: This matter is so technical that adetailed description of it would only confuse the House, but it is referred to in more detail in the technical report that I have tabled..

speech.para: Then the Minister continued to mislead the House, and said -

quote.para: All the evidence is to the effect that the Company is meticulous in the discharge of its obligations, both technical and financial.

speech.para: His only reference to the admission that the faulty parts had been assembled in an aircraft was contained in one veiled reference to the matter when he made the following statement -

item.para: . it was not until parts made by Chrysler Australia Limited werefitted into the assembly fixture at Fishermen's Bend that the discrepancies became apparent.

speech.para: There was no reference to the aircraft. The right honorable gentleman called the aircraft an assembly fixture, and the House did not detect in those words the slightest suggestion that he was speaking about the reference in the report to an aircraft.
I draw the attention of this House to what the technical report says regarding my charge concerning rear walls. Last week I made the following statement : -

quote.para: These rear walls were supposed to be curved on the outer surface to match, the wing contours. This was not done. They were folded straight instead of being folded with a curve and the metal was scraped away to givethe required contour.

speech.para: This is what the technical report states -

quote.para: The statement that these parts should be curved is correct. It is also correct that the error was not noticed until the part was assembled into the aircraft and before the error was found a number of parts had been made by Chrysler Australia Limited-.

speech.para: This is the technical report that the Minister did not read to the House. In the report that he gave to the House he gave the impression that no faulty part was ever assembled into an aircraft.
In reference to escape hatches, I said -

quote.para: The navigator's escape hatches. When they were being made they did not match up on the various jigs because the jigs were not properly matched, and the next stage was to distort them to make them fit the jigs . . .

speech.para: The technical report reads -

quote.para: C.A.I... experienced difficulty in manufacturing this* component in the initial stages of production and the control provided by the jig was not sufficient to ensure interchangeability. . . . The problem could not bc fully appreciated until components were assembled into aircraft.

speech.para: Again we find that another faulty part was assembled in the aircraft, as is revealed in the technical report that the Minister refrained from giving to the House. He did something worse than that. He suggested that the technical report did not disclose any faults in the parts that were produced. In fact, he said, to use his own words, that the company was meticulous in the discharge of its obligations. He suggested that no faulty parts were made by Chrysler Australia Limited, and he said that there certainly was not any suggestion that any faulty parts were fitted to the aircraft.

talk.start.para: - I am surprised that the honorable member for Gippsland should object to the ventilation of a matter such as this. I read from the technical report as follows: -

quote.para: The problem could not be fully appreciated until components were assembled into aircraft in Melbourne and out of a total of 13 components produced by C.A.L., one was returned to CAX. for rework.

speech.para: Not only that, but this section of the report also supports other charges that were made. The report contained these words also -

quote.para: It is correct to state that in the past these stringers had been, in some instances, cold worked to a greater extent than is considered good practice ... It must be clearly understood that the practice referred to above is now discontinued and could not result in the manufacture of stringers that would endanger the safety of the aircraft.

speech.para: Where have all the stringers that have been made and put into the aircraft, perhaps before this discrepancy was first detected, gone?

I now believe that the Minister is showing greater concern for protecting Chrysler Australia Limited than . for the interests of the nation and its defence, and more interest in Chrysler Australia Limited than in the people, who are called upon to provide the enormous sums of money that are expended each year on the defence of Australia. The Minister's action has cast serious doubts on his suitability to advise the House of the facts of the matter, and for this reason alone the Opposition's demand for an impartial inquiry into all aspects of the matter on which information has been given to me carries greater weight than ever.

talk.start.para: . - in reply - It was very interest- ing to hear the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) try to make his own escape hatch and get out of the mess that he has got himself into.
- Let the Minister tell us why he suppressed the report.
- The hounds are barking.
-Order ! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

- I withdraw it. The noise in the House forced me to make it. On the occasion to which the honorable member for Hindmarsh has referred, I invited his attention to the fact that if he had kept to the inspectors' cards from which he obtained his information, which were in the main correct, without giving the matter the sinister twist that he gave to it, he would have done some service to the community. I invite his attention to the fact that I contested, not what he read from the cards, but only his own observations. The second point that I make in relation to the honorable member's charge is that I tabled a report that the House and the whole country can read.
- Why did the Minister not read it?
- I did not seek to cloak it.
- The Minister did seek to do that.
- I summarized it.
- The Minister said that it was too technical.

- If honorable members opposite tell me that when a report is tabled in this House it is not public property, I should like to know what is. I tabled the report, and I then summarized it. I told the honorable member for Hindmarsh that if he had kept to the inspectors' cards and not given the matter a sinister twist, he would have been reasonably correct. The honorable member has now endeavoured to get out of his predicament by making charges. But I pass over that point.

speech.para: The honorable member made another series of charges. I propose to deal with two or three of them just to show the honorable member's irresponsibility in making statements to the House. His first statement related to danger to the Canberra aircraft. The honorable member mentioned the Amberley crash and said that the Canberra bombers should not go into the air, and that if a crash occurred within twelve months we would remember his words. He said that faulty parts were being built into Canberra bombers. He has since said that faulty parts were not fitted to Canberra aircraft, but were built into assemblies. The whole of the report of the technical committee laid emphasis upon the fact that the Canberra aircraft was not in danger from anything about which the honorable member for Hindmarsh has complained.

The honorable member for Hindmarsh came back to the attack, and I propose to deal with two or three points to show the House how irresponsible he has been. He said that the Birlec electric furnace ran for sixteen hours at a time, at a cost of Â£8 an hour, loaded with only a small number of parts that were being precipitation heat treated. What are the facts? This furnace takes approximately three hours to reach full heat treatment temperature saturation and, so far as the company is able to ensure, is fully loaded with planned heat treatment batches except in instances where parts urgently required by the government aircraft factories have to be heat treated other than in planned batches. I have no doubt that the honorable member referred to such an occasion. At the precipitation heat treatment temperature of 140 degrees centigrade, the furnace costs approximately 15s. an hour to run, and not Â£8 an hour as he stated. Every observation that the honorable member makes reveals his ignorance of the facts, and shows that some junior officer has been giving him this information.

The honorable member mentioned Mi. White. Mr. White, who is one of the foremen of Chrysler Australia Limited, overrode a decision of a company inspector and placed his own stamp on the work. The honorable member made a lot out of that and gave it a very sinister twist. He said that here was something thai should be investigated. But let us consider the facts. Mr. White is a foreman inspector, not a foreman in production, and was supervising the inspector concerned. It is the responsibility of a foreman inspector to adjudicate where necessary and, as the more senior inspector, he is permitted to accept a part with which he is satisfied, and must then place his own stamp on the work. In this instance, that is exactly what happened. White accepted the part entirely on his own responsibility, and this is why foremen inspectors are employed. A junior inspector of the Aeronautical Inspection Directorate complained to White about the action that he had taken, and White stood by his decision. No complaint by the Aeronautical Inspection Directorate was submitted in writing about White overriding his own inspector. There is nothing abnormal in an inspector overriding from time to time a decision made by one of his junior officers. The honorable member made another irresponsible statement about that matter and sought to gain some political advantage out of it.

The honorable member mentioned also a statement made by government aircraft factory officer Taylor to Chrysler Australia Limited inspector Lee, at Chrysler Australia Limited, concerning a faulty drop tank, which was delivered by the company to Fishermen's Bend, and which grounded the aircraft. The government aircraft factory received a tank that contained foreign matter. The Chrysler Australia Limited assistant aircraft manager- and the Chrysler Australia Limited factory superintendent were brought over from Melbourne in connexion with this matter. These officers, together with government aircraft factory and Aeronautical Inspection Directorate officers, inspected the tank in question on the 12th January, 1954. When the Chrysler- Australia Limited officers returned to Adelaide after their visit, they arranged for corrective action to he taken to ensure that this error would not be repeated, and it has not been repeated, the honorable member for- Hindmarsh complained of something, that was corrected by the system of supervision that is in operation, and he still seeks to find fault with. it. I cannot understand his reasoning. Let us have a look at another matter that he mentioned. He spoke of an alteration of a tool drawing, said that it bad been inscribed, and asked me toimpound' the drawing.

talk.start.para: - That is right.

-Let. the honorable member state the facts. Government aircraft factory production engineering, instruction No. 15, issue 1, dated the. 25th May, 1951, and current issue. 2,. dated the 4th July, 1951, authorize major sub-contractors to alter tool, drawings under certain circumstances, provided details of alterations are subsequently sent to the government aircraft factories tool design office. The fact that Chrysler Australia Limited altered a tool drawing is not in itself any evidence of malpractice^ Details- of the alterations that were referred to by the honorable member for Hindmarsh would have to be examined to determine if Chrysler Australia- Limited had exceeded itsauthority in that instance. Even if it had, the matter is only of minor significance, as aircraft safety would not be affected. The aircraft design- drawings and not the tool drawings control the safety of the aircraft. Honorable members must be able to detect the irresponsibility of the honorable member for Hindmarsh. He has made irresponsible, mischievous and untrustworthy statements in. this. House.
- Rubbish !
- Order !

- I would not recommend to the Prima Minister (Mr. Menzies) that the people's- money or the valuable time of honorable members should be wasted to- satisfy the exhibi- tionism of the honorable member for Hindmarsh. From the time- that the honorable member stated that a Canberrabomber would explode in mid-air if the canopy of a Jindivik target aircraft were fitted to the- bomber-
- The Minister for Defence Production does not know what lie is talking about.

- The: honorable member for Eden-Monaro- (Mr. Allan- Fraser)- is- maintaining a running series of interjections, but he- knows nothing, about the discussion. He was not in the House when the statement was made;
- Order ! I insist that all interjections on both sides- of the House shall, cease.

- From the time that the. honorable, member for Hindmarsh said that a Canberra bomber would explode in the air if the canopy of a Jindivik target aircraft were fitted to it, he. has been writhing in an endeavour to get. out of the mess.
-Order! If the honorable member for Lalor interjects again, I shall name him.

- The honorable member for Hindmarsh, made- a series- of statements in this House, in an endeavour to get clear of the mess into which he had put himself. On every count I have proved him wrong.. Now he has. claimed, that. I have misled the House. How could I do. that when I tabled a. report from which the honorable member himself has quoted at length? The whole of his statement was directed at the alleged insecurity and lack of safety of the Canberra bomber. He has been proved wrong in every statement, and I defy the honorable member to say that there is anything in that report, to support his claim that the safety of the Canberra bomber h as been affected. Now the honorable member has made a vicious attack upon Chrysler- Australia Limited!. In effect, be has stated that Chrysler An&tralia Limited has: been trying- to beat the system and that the system has not succumbed to the attempt. In the face of that, he has demanded that the Government should set up a judicial inquiry to investigate his allegation that Chrysler. Australia limited had been trying to beat the system, whereas, in fact, that organization has not beaten the system and has made noattempt to do so.
- Order! The Minister's time has aspired: .
